newsitem.title: ITALY: EU's Bonino says commission report "unbalanced".
newsitem.headline: EU's Bonino says commission report "unbalanced".

text.p: European Commissioner Emma Bonino said on Monday that she thought an EU document due for release this week, which newspaper reports have said will show Italy outside a key single currency parameter, seemed unfair.

"I think the document seems unbalanced. On Wednesday, we will need to look into the reasons which have led the experts to such an evaluation," the Social Affairs Commissioner, an Italian, told reporters in Rome.
The European Union's executive commission is due to release a document of official economic forecasts on Wednesday.

Newspaper reports have said that the EU document will show only Italy and Greece outside the key target of a three percent deficit to gross domestic product in 1997 required to join Europe's planned economic and monetary union.
An EU source has said Italy's deficit this year was forecast at 3.2 percent of GDP.
"I'm not convinced by the sums," Bonino said on the fringe of a convention in Rome. She added that in Brussels "there's a battle under way".
Bonino said constant leaks and reports were alarmist and unhelpful, and that there were difficulties for all EU states.
European countries will be judged next year on whether their economic performance is good enough for them to join EMU at its scheduled launch on January 1, 1999.
"I'm told the International Monetary Fund forecasts a deficit-GDP ratio for Italy, France and Germany of 3.2-3.3 percent in 1997," Bonino said.

"I'm not so blind I can't see that France is going to have early elections to push through an additional budget and the reason for (German Chancellor Helmut) Kohl's decision to stand again," she said.
Chirac is due to make an television address later today, amid expectations he will call an early general election in May or June. Kohl announced recently he would seek re-election.
